message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's recent bout of optic neuritis, pulmonary sarcoidosis, hypertension, and right-sided facial droop suggest a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS). The most appropriate treatment for MS is a combination of high-dose methylprednisolone and a disease-modifying agent, such as methotrexate. Heparin and plasmapheresis are not indicated in the management of MS.

The recent optic neuritis episode and possible facial droop also suggest these diagnoses. MRI would be helpful in diagnosing and differentiating between NMO and MS. We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of multiple sclerosis (MS), including acute optic neuritis, dizziness, and disorientation. The recent use of IV methylprednisolone also supports the diagnosis. The right-sided facial droop may indicate a new or worsening lesion in the brainstem. The most appropriate next step in management would be to initiate therapy with high-dose IV methylprednisolone and add methotrexate to reduce the risk of future exacerbations. Heparin is not indicated in this case, as there is no evidence of thrombotic disease. Plasmapheresis may be considered in severe cases of MS or when patients do not respond to steroid therapy. However, it is not the first-line treatment for a patient with a new onset of MS symptoms like this.
